title: Miri/CTFE fails when const generic is used as value

labels.name: requires-nightly
labels.description: This issue requires a nightly compiler in some way.

body:
Miri/CTFE fails to execute code where a const generic parameter is used as a value, such as what `try_from` for arrays does these days:

```rust
#![feature(const_generics)]

fn len<'a, T, const N: usize>(_array: &'a [T; N]) -> usize { N }

fn main() {
    const N: usize = 16;
    type Array = [u8; N];
    let array: Array = [0; N];
    len(&array);
}
```
yields
```
error[E0080]: Miri evaluation error: encountered overly generic constant
 --> src/main.rs:3:62
  |
3 | fn len<'a, T, const N: usize>(_array: &'a [T; N]) -> usize { N }
  |                                                              ^ Miri evaluation error: encountered overly generic constant
  |
```

The "obvious" fix seems to be to call `monomorphize` on the const before evaluating it; i did that in https://github.com/RalfJung/rust/commit/a8754d4d33. However, that ICEs:

The backtrace shows that it is the first `monomorphize` in `eval_const_to_op` that fails. The backtrace also involves const-prop -- of course it does, there is hardly any ICE for the Miri engine that does not.

@eddyb says

> What constprop should do is use identity Substs, that match the ParamEnv it should already be using (otherwise it'd get ICEs all over the place).

I am not sure what this means.^^ @oli-obk does this help to find the ICE that currently prevents supporting const-generics? It's something in const-prop again. :/
